response:
*1. When you think about the environmental impact of software, who comes to
mind as responsible for it, and why did that person or group come to mind?*

When I think about the environmental impact of software, I do not picture a
single owner. I think of the people whose decisions shape how systems
behave once they are in production. Engineers and architects come to mind
first because every design choice they make becomes energy somewhere in the
chain. Their decisions influence CPU cycles, memory use, network traffic,
and overall data movement, which eventually turn into electricity consumed.
Platform and cloud teams follow naturally, because the way they configure
scaling, instance sizes, containers, limits, and runtime defaults
establishes the baseline efficiency of everything that runs on top of it.
Product owners and engineering managers also influence the outcome because
they decide which work gets prioritised and when teams are allowed to slow
down and optimise rather than rushing new features out the door. Vendors
play a role as well because their managed services and opaque systems
dictate how much energy is already consumed before an organisation touches
the code. Leadership completes the picture, because the framing they give
to engineering work defines whether sustainability becomes a real concern
or something easily pushed aside.

Even with all these groups in mind, I start from a belief that most people
genuinely want to make good choices. Teams rarely ignore sustainability out
of bad intent. They are simply under pressure to ship, to hit deadlines,
and to keep up with demand. In that reality responsibility becomes
distributed not because no one cares but because the work is fast moving
and full of trade offs that accumulate into environmental impact whether
anyone intended it or not.
------------------------------

*2. In your experience, who is currently making decisions about the
environmental impact of software? Is it the right set of people?*

In practice most decisions that influence the environmental impact of
software are made indirectly. Infrastructure teams shape energy usage
through scaling policies and provisioning choices even when sustainability
is not their explicit focus. FinOps teams try to optimise cloud bills,
which sometimes aligns with energy efficiency and sometimes does not.
Developers influence efficiency through their design and coding choices but
usually only when they have the time, and when the impact is visible enough
to matter during a sprint. ESG teams track carbon footprints for reporting
purposes, yet they are rarely in a position to change the underlying
technical decisions. Vendors and cloud providers also make decisions on the
customer’s behalf simply through the way their platforms behave.

So the decision making today is scattered. The people involved are partly
the right people but they are not aligned in a way that supports
intentional action. Operational leaders often focus on staying within
shrinking budgets rather than addressing systemic inefficiencies. CFO level
oversight tends to appear when costs explode, not as a partner in
sustainable design. And because most delivery teams operate under constant
pressure the idea of stopping to reduce waste rarely makes it into the
planning cycle.

This is why I believe organisations need a cleanup crew, a dedicated group
focused on the areas with the highest footprint or the highest cost or the
greatest user scale or the most critical business processes. Their work
would not replace engineering teams but rather support them by identifying
where improvements matter most. For this to work they would need explicit
support from the board. Without that kind of sponsorship sustainability
remains optional and easily overridden by short term deadlines.
------------------------------

*3. What barriers have you or your organisation encountered when trying to
address software’s environmental impact?*

The biggest barrier is a lack of visibility. Most organisations cannot see
energy consumption at the level where engineering and architectural
decisions are made. Without clear insight into watt hours per request or
the energy cost of specific code paths sustainability becomes abstract
rather than actionable. A second barrier is the constant pressure to
deliver. Teams want to make improvements yet deadlines, customer
expectations, and issue backlogs push efficiency work out of view. Another
barrier is the separation between ESG reporting and engineering practice.
Sustainability data and software design often live in completely different
parts of the organisation, which makes alignment difficult. Cloud
abstraction adds another obstacle because much of the energy footprint is
controlled by services that teams cannot see or influence directly.
Cultural assumptions also appear such as the belief that sustainability
belongs to someone else or that the gains are too small to matter even
though many improvements can reduce waste by orders of magnitude.

There is also a human dimension that matters a lot. People generally want
to do the right thing. Engineers and managers and operational staff care
about quality and efficiency but they work inside systems full of time
pressure, unpredictable incidents, and competing demands. Operational
leaders often focus on keeping budgets stable rather than reducing waste at
the systemic level. These constraints make it hard for teams to address
environmental impact consistently.

This is why a cleanup crew is needed. A focused group that can identify and
address inefficiencies in the highest impact areas allows the rest of the
organisation to keep delivering while still reducing waste. And without
board level support such an effort cannot overcome the structural and
cultural pressures that keep sustainability work on the sidelines. When the
board backs it sustainability becomes part of how the organisation operates
rather than an optional good intention.
